4215: Cruel Tutor.author: DarthParallax
4215: Cruel Tutor.text_parsed:
Boomy? is that you?! what happened to you?!

Calculus and crack cocaine!

Very Well Designed card. I haven't played with Vampiric Tutor much yet, but I just bought one and I know for a fact Demonic Tutor is as dumb as Entomb, and they needed a lot of nerfing.

Grim Tutor is probably the Best All-around Tutor. From the perspectives of not ONLY Power, but Gameplay Fun. It being not-banned in Prismatic yet happens to be one of the signs of this, but I'll wager it's not so much that people play a ton of Prismatic, as it is that they play a Ton of Magic in general, and Grim Tutor looks more fun to play than Cruel Tutor OR Demonic Tutor. It's also much rarer than Vampiric Tutor, which has a Core Set printing.

Vampiric Tutor is highly Constructed Playable, but it's also got that Core Set Reprint, so there's a LOT more copies out there than there are of Grim Tutor. I'm not sure what the supply and demand curves look like *exactly* for Vampiric vs. Grim, but Grim looks very well positioned to be in a Sweet Spot.
?

4217: Dread Reaper.author: Equinox523
4217: Dread Reaper.text_parsed:
Guys, context is everything. Remember that this came in Portal, which had no instant speed removal, and also very few huge fliers. It's also black, so one of the main means of removal is gone. In case you're wondering, here are the only fliers with power 5 or more in the set:

Archangel (5/5)
Cloud Dragon (5/4)
Djinn of the Lamp (5/6)
Ebon Dragon (5/4)
Fire Dragon (6/6)

This could kill all of them. It also illustrates a core concept of black as a color: its willingness to do anything to win, including wager life.

Man, I remember this being one of my first cards when I was really young and just getting into Magic. I thought it was the coolest thing ever - like, IT NEVER DIES. WHAT.

why dose this set always have the worst reminder text,

Draw a card (You draw from your deck)
Destroy all creatures (This includes your creatures)
Swamp Walk (A swamp is in play regardless of weather or not it is tapped or untapped.)
Destroy target creature if it isn't black (A creature is black if it has {B} in its mana cost.)
You lose the game at the end of that turn (You don't lose the game if you already won.)
You may chose to tap any one creature (Tapped creatures cant intercept)
Deals damage equal to the number of mountains you have in play (This includes booth tapped and untapped
mountains)
When Serpent Warrior comes into play from your hand, you lose 3 life. (The person who plays Serpent Warrior loses the life.)
All white creatures get +2/+0 (This includes other players white creatures)
And my personal favorite
All creatures you control get +1/+1 until end of turn (For example, a 1/2 would become a 2/3)

(Not Portal Second edition or any of the other ones like that.)

4249: Baleful Stare.author: Mode
4249: Baleful Stare.text_parsed:
@bijart_dauth: Haha great list. It's a beginner set yes, but still:
Portal has such a big amount of senseless reminder text, it's like Captain Obvious was in the design team for this set.
You'd be surprised though, some players would in fact play the card wrong without these no-brainer reminder texts.

Another interesting aspect of Portal is it's "demystifying nature". The your library is called "deck" even during play, and the graveyard simply becomes a "discard pile".

Pretty much the opposite of what Wizards does these days:
"In play" now is "on the battlefield", the removed-from-the-game-zone is now the "exile", and "is put into a graveyard from play" on creatures is now "dies". (I'd have prefered using the former keyword "buried" for this purpose on any permanent though, since this current inconsistency messes up the wording of triggers that are affected by both creatures and something else like artifacts for example. But that's a different story...)

My prediction on this card's oracle in a even more flavor-filled future of Magic:
"Look into target player's mind. You recall for each Mountain and red thought in it."

(Probably flavor overdosed, at least reagarding the replacement of "card" for "thought".)

But that's a different story...)

I'll just mention that that reminder text is there to underline that draw means drawing from your deck, whereas this could be interpreted as drawing cards out of your opponent's hand.

Though perhaps recall would be more suited for returning stuff from your GY. That'd be a much appreciated keyword, I feel like. Perhaps drawing could be replaced by Ponder X.

4253: Cloud Pirates.author: Salient
4253: Cloud Pirates.text_parsed:
It's a-me, Mario! I'm-a here with my friends, from Dragonball-Z!

...I have to admit, Master of Etherium's comment made me laugh -- possibly his only actually funny comment.

The use of 'intercept' for 'block' was actually a pretty good idea, since the word 'intercept' matches the mechanics a little better. It really did help new players avoid the "my creature attacks your creature" misconception. Wizards should have switched over comprehensively while they had the chance; using 'intercept' only in the Starter level product, then promptly dropping it, was a bad call.

I second Ideatog - this art style's really enjoyable, and Foglio was one of the best. The art lately (especially in the Innistrad block) is gorgeous and evocative and wonderful, but it's been a while since the art on a card made me grin like this one does.

Yet i dislike the Oracle wording, since there were not any instants in Portal, therefore i guess they would have enabled this card to search for instants as well actually...

4271: Personal Tutor.author: ChaosFire
4271: Personal Tutor.text_parsed:
Everyone complaining about this card not searching for instants, please listen.

Portal didn't have instants. Even the counterspell was a sorcery. It didn't mean "instant or sorcery," it meant sorcery. Wizards thought the target audience for Portal would be too confused by anything faster than sorcery speed.

That said, the only reason we even talk about this card is because Mystical Tutor got banned in Legacy. Yes, we all want it to be Mystical Tutor. But then it would be banned too, and combo decks would have been even more broken when they were legal.

As it is, the card works just fine in some combo decks, still being able to grab a Reanimate or Doomsday. Is it ideal? No. But it still works as the most effective non-Grim tutor for those decks, and when paired with the ability to draw cards, the "top of deck" clause doesn't even hurt that much.
4271: Personal Tutor.text_posted:

That said, the only reason we even talk about this card is because Mystical Tutor got banned in Legacy. Yes, we all want it to be Mystical Tutor. But then it would be banned too, and combo decks would have been even more broken when they were legal.

As it is, the card works just fine in some combo decks, still being able to grab a Reanimate or Doomsday. Is it ideal? No. But it still works as the most effective non-Grim tutor for those decks, and when paired with the ability to draw cards, the "top of deck" clause doesn't even hurt that much.

Either those people don't like the artwork that much, or they simply didn't know about the combo potential involving infinite mana.
Stroke of Genius is more famous for that use since it can also have use without serving as a finisher.
The problem with Prosperty is that, despite being a draw spell, it causes card disadvantage compared to your opponent.
You could always run cards like Underworld Dreams to compensate this when not aming for a way to spend plenty of mana from a loop, though.

4277: Symbol of Unsummoning.author: BigBoyBrian
4277: Symbol of Unsummoning.text_parsed:
There *are* times when you would prefer the sorcery speed instead of the instant, particularly for the noob player. Yes, I know, you are all experts and these mistakes could never happen to you, but some people could benefit from the extra few seconds needed to think through their options.

A newly casted creature typically has summoning sickness and as such is no threat the turn it is summoned. Here are some examples where a noob is better off with the sorcery speed removal.

Example 1: Player 1: I cast Lowland Giant and now I cast....
Player 2: "Hah! I unsummon!"
Player 1: ..... "Ok, was going to cast an enchant on him, but nvm, I'll wait until next turn".

Example 2: Player 1: "I cast Raging Goblin"
Player 2: "Hah! I unsummon!"
Player 1: "Dude, you know I have more mana, right?"

Example 3: Player 1: " I tap two mana and cast..."
Player 2: "Hah! I unsummon your Wall of Blossoms!"
Player 1: "Yup that's fine"

And no, I am not saying I prefer sorcery to instant.

Pretty much all of the spells in this vein have the same flavour - Unyaro Bee Sting is functionally identical to this one, and was the first of its kind; since then, they have added Unyaro Bees as another Time Spiral "nod to the past", and very recently Hornet Sting has been added to the list.

A dedicated theme-deck builder probably has enough cards to make an actual theme deck for bees, wasps and hornets. How effective such a deck would be is... questionable... but it would be cool to see!

I probably wouldn't put more than one in my deck though. It's the kind of spell you only want to play once, and not until pretty late in the game when you've got a significant amount of forests.

4299: Gorilla Warrior.author: humor_love
4299: Gorilla Warrior.text_parsed:
This is meant to provide a little early-to-mid game beef in a deck that includes Green but is not predominantly Green. In such a context, this card can be decent.

Strangely, I find that if I start sliding Green into a deck to provide 'Green support', I tend to convert the deck into a Green deck that is supported by the other color(s). Green's mana ramp is pretty powerful, but it usually calls for {G} production at the earliest opportunity, rather than secondarily.

4307: Natural Order.author: Elysiume
4307: Natural Order.text_parsed:
They changed, pretty significantly, how the card works with the oracle text.

Original: "Put a green creature into play from your library. Then sacrifice a creature."
Oracle: "Sacrifice a creature as an additional cost to play this. Put a green creature into play from your library."

Now, you can only cast it if you have a green creature to sacrifice upfront. Why would they do that?
4307: Natural Order.text_posted:

4307: Natural Order.author: heenaheena
4307: Natural Order.text_parsed:
@ Elysiume,
Portal came out in June of 1997. This card was first printed in Visions which came out in January of 1997. The Visions version makes you sacrifice a creature as part of the cost so I guess they chose to go with the original. Also, if you sacrificed a creature after searching for it, this card would be strictly better than it is right now and it doesn't need to be. You could basically use it like Flash (banned in legacy for good reason) and then auto-win with any of the Protean Hulk combos (search for Heart Sliver and 3x Virulent Sliver). Granted Natural Order has converted mana cost of 4 rather than Flash's cmc of two, but you wouldn't even need the Hulk in your hand and would probably wouldn't need more than one in your deck.
4307: Natural Order.text_posted:
@ Elysiume,

Dear Wizards,

Reprint this please!

4307: Natural Order.author: Quadrisphere
4307: Natural Order.text_parsed:
Green Tinker. I never understood why this card is not very famous wheras that is banned in legacy and all. For a cmc of just 1 more, you can have a much more effective tutoring effect depending on the deck you are playing it in, and the stuff you can search out are basically just as good.

I also don't understand why this card has such a big power level errata while stuff like Time Vault are left alone. If you play this card as printed, you can use it to essentially flash a card from deck and sacrifice it right away. Also it would be able to play Iname as One and search for another (because it says play it "as if you just played it from your hand.")

4310: Nature's Lore.author: Bbone37
4310: Nature's Lore.text_parsed:
today must be Nature's Lore day for me....

This is neither better nor worse than rampant growth. This fetches duals and effectively cost since the forest comes into play untapped. So major points for this card, yes.

Rampant growth would be better in a deck with out access to dual lands, and one that is in need of a land that is not a forest.

Both have their place, and while this one is generally better, there are many viable reasons where a rampant growth would be better.

Lastly, Kryplixx the "<" means is less than... you basically agreed with thaviel even though you thought you were disagreeing with him.

4320: Sylvan Tutor.author: NobuTheBard
4320: Sylvan Tutor.text_parsed:
It's a rare sorcery because it was printed for Portal. Portal was the first "starter" set and focused on a simplified ruleset to introduce the game to new players. It didn't contain instants or interrupts (among other things), so numerous cards were reworkings of existing spells at sorcery speed. In this case, Worldly Tutor. A weird result of this is some very strange timing restrictions on some sorceries meant for combat tricks, like Harsh Justice or Blessed Reversal. You can see it also used a different vocabulary, referring to "summon cards" and actually calling to your deck as such, rather than as a library.

I don't know the story behind the rarity, especially when you see something like Personal Tutor was printed at uncommon. Personal Tutor was effectively similar to like, Merchant Scroll, which was a common (...in Homelands, anyway). Cruel Tutor, as an attempted at a redone Demonic Tutor, was also printed as a Rare. Maybe because the set was very creature-focused, so this looked like a stronger card? There's also fellow rare green creature tutor Natural Order in the same set.

As this card was never reprinted, copies of it can fetch a lot more than Worldly Tutor. Like, 6 times as much, as of this comment.
4320: Sylvan Tutor.text_posted:
It's a rare sorcery because it was printed for Portal.  Portal was the first "starter" set and focused on a simplified ruleset to introduce the game to new players.  It didn't contain instants or interrupts (among other things), so numerous cards were reworkings of existing spells at sorcery speed.  In this case, [autocard]Worldly Tutor[/autocard].  A weird result of this is some very strange timing restrictions on some sorceries meant for combat tricks, like [autocard]Harsh Justice[/autocard] or [autocard]Blessed Reversal[/autocard].  You can see it also used a different vocabulary, referring to "summon cards" and actually calling to your deck as such, rather than as a library.

Personal Tutor was effectively similar to like, [autocard]Merchant Scroll[/autocard], which was a [i]common[/i] (...in Homelands, anyway).  [autocard]Cruel Tutor[/autocard], as an attempted at a redone [autocard]Demonic Tutor[/autocard], was also printed as a Rare.  Maybe because the set was very creature-focused, so this looked like a stronger card?  There's also fellow rare green creature tutor [autocard]Natural Order[/autocard] in the same set.

As this card was never reprinted, copies of it can fetch a lot more than Worldly Tutor.  Like, 6 times as much, as of this comment.

4320: Sylvan Tutor.author: DarthParallax
4320: Sylvan Tutor.text_parsed:
Tutor History:

Demonic Tutor: Basically, really dumb. It's an Uncommon, it's 2-mana, it gets you anything, IT'S BLACK, and it has No Drawback. It goes directly to your hand and you don't have to reveal it. It doesn't have a single one of the restrictions that basically every other Tutor card in the game has. It's at least, not an Instant.

Playtesting and Real World Results showed that Demonic Tutor was Not OK, and also that it would have been better to have at Instant Speed, so you could play it on your opponents' turn, untap on your turn, then actually cast what you fetched.

Mirage: Enlightened Tutor, Mystical Tutor, Vampiric Tutor, Worldly Tutor. They still hadn't got a good grip on Mana Costs. For Instant Speed (actually a plus to playability without being Game Breaking) it would have been fine to have these cost 2 Mana, but they were going by "More Restricted Use than Demonic Tutor, better charge less Mana). Increased Rarity was also Completely Appropriate, as a Search for a Spell is USUALLY worth being Rare. (Some Land Searching should be lower Rarities, and is.) Uncommon Search Effects are hard to Design, but there exist some that make sense and don't feel pushed.

Portal: Portal's first set was released essentially after Mirage Block. (I consider Mirage and Visions to be a 2-set Block with Weatherlight kind of an odd hanger-on that segues into the Real next Block, Tempest. Weatherlight was printed after 5th Edition by my research. I could be wrong, but this is still Early Years of MAGIC, so weird things like the timing here can be expected.) Anyway, Portal's cycle of Tutors was clearly Based on Mirage's, but it had even more experience to work with, and decided to tone down the Power Level of Tutoring even further.



Diabolic Tutor appeared in Odyssey Block and 8th Edition, which is about as soon after 5th Edition, as 5th Edition is from Alpha, and that's just about the History of Tutors in R&D. There are a lot more Recent ones, but the actual Conventions of What is acceptable Power Levels or not hasn't changed much since the first printing of Diabolic, except that Odyssey tinkered with searching to put things into Graveyards, and Mirrodin tried out Searching for Equipment, and pretty much those cards are currently "No-Nos" for Power Level (won't be seen in Standard Again.) The Big Giant from Morningtide is plenty reprintable for fetching Equipment, but other Equipment Fetches, um, aren't.

4324: Whiptail Wurm.text_parsed:
Presenting a comprehensive list of the best monogreen vanilla creatures per CMC, by highest power and toughness, to date (only "true" vanilla creatures, and not "virtual vanillas" like WIld Nacatl):

1 Mana:
Norwood Ranger, 1/2
Trained Jackal, 1/2
Woodland Druid, 1/2

2 Mana:
Kalonian Tusker, 3/2
Swordwise Centaur, 3/2
Elvish Warrior, 2/3

3 Mana:
Leatherback Baloth, 4/5

4 Mana:
Rumbling Baloth, 4/4

5 Mana:
Panther Warriors, 6/3
Silverback Ape, 5/5
Hollowhenge Beast, 5/5
Pheres-Band Centaurs, 3/7

6 Mana:
Vorstclaw, 7/7

7 Mana:
Quilled Slagwurm, 8/8

8 Mana:
Scaled Wurm, 7/6

As you can see, this more splashable than Quilled Slagwurm, but has less toughness. Still, for a very long time this was the most powerful monogreen vanilla for 7 mana.

4334: Devastation.author: sarroth
4334: Devastation.text_parsed:
There are two good reasons to consider this card over Obliterate:

1) This card does not destroy artifacts or prevent things from regenerating. While this means there may be more permanents your opponents get to keep, that also means this card is easier for you to build around, requiring fewer enchantments thrown into the deck to be able to truly abuse the effect.

2) It can be countered. This is a positive because many, many players dislike land destruction and some players dislike Wrath of God effects. Players generally dislike noninteraction, and one way to not interact with other players is to have a nearly (note that I say nearly, given Time Stop and Mindbreak Trap) unanswerable effect that, if played correctly (say, with Avacyn, Angel of Hope or Eldrazi Monument) ends the game. Giving them an out - and even more so, a reason to like Counterspells - may go a long way toward a healthy playgroup even as you run generally controversial effects.

2) It can be countered. This is a positive because many, many players dislike land destruction and some players dislike [autocard]Wrath of God[/autocard] effects. Players generally dislike noninteraction, and one way to not interact with other players is to have a nearly (note that I say nearly, given [autocard]Time Stop[/autocard] and [autocard]Mindbreak Trap[/autocard]) unanswerable effect that, if played correctly (say, with [autocard]Avacyn, Angel of Hope[/autocard] or [autocard]Eldrazi Monument[/autocard]) ends the game. Giving them an out - and even more so, a reason to like [autocard]Counterspell[/autocard]s - may go a long way toward a healthy playgroup even as you run generally controversial effects.

4336: Fire Dragon.author: Kirbster
4336: Fire Dragon.text_parsed:
What's the best thing about this card?

Is it the fact it's a big dragon that comes with a Spitting Earth? Okay, this is pretty cool, so we're getting it out of the way. Considering he's nine mana, and can only target creatures, it's going to be an excessively large Spitting Earth... but targeted removal is nothing to ignore. Still, why couldn't it have been a Jaws of Stone effect? Bogardan Hellkite did that right. And why couldn't it have at least nailed your opponent? Regardless, it's a nice little ability.

Is it the fact that... hold on, the fire's coming out of it's tail?! What the Hell is that? Big-ass dragon with an open mouth, and it's decided he should be shooting fire out of his tail? Who is responsible for this? Why does he have a Volcano Hellion grafted to his ass?

Is it the... okay, wait. "Fire Dragon"? Seriously? What are you, six? You had to resort to the most boring, generic, run-of-the-mill name possible for a dragon that comes with a 9+ point fireball? Why not print "Dead Zombie" while you're at it, too? The worst part may be that while this card was given the most generic dragon name possible - something I would have understood on the original Shivan, but no, even then they got it right - yet at the same time they decided to totally pull one from left field and give it a nonconformist firebreathing ass.

Is it the... you know what? No. The more I talk about this card, the angrier I get. It got a free ride just because it's from Portal and thus more obscure.

Screw this guy. He's not necessarily bad, but... screw him.

4337: Fire Imp.author: oraymw
4337: Fire Imp.text_parsed:
Oraymw's Random Card Comment 6/14/2011

Heheheh. I just couldn't help but get in on the fun. Why should just R&D people be able to comment on cards.

Guess what. The very first Magic cards I ever owned were from Portal. And this guy was in my very first booster pack. I've made a lot of use of him since then, and he's found his way into my budget cube.

This is one of the guys that taught me about card advantage. At first, he seemed mediocre to me, since he just had a 2/1 body. But eventually I saw how powerful a free 2 damage could be, especially in the Portal set. This was a game changing card to drop on turn 3.

I think this is a creature that actually holds up well according to modern design sensibilities. I wonder if it would be updated to have a may ability now, or if it would be left as is. In any case, it would be a rock solid limited card.

I always loved the flavor of this guy that jumped onto the field and burned another creature away, but then he ran out of fire and just sits there as a mediocre creature. Great card.

4354: Pyroclasm.author: Salient
4354: Pyroclasm.text_parsed:
I love this card.

I always play four of these in a mono-red burn deck, alongside four Firespout. If I need a little more utility, I put one of each in the sideboard, to snag with a Burning Wish. (Against noncreature decks that are low on critter removal, I sideboard in four Magus of the Moon.)

Those two burn spells are massive card advantage in disguise, and critters not quite killed by the 'clasm can be targeted with a secondary burn spell. Not an ideal solution, but pretty good.

4359: Rain of Salt.author: Brazz_Herald
4359: Rain of Salt.text_parsed:
I owned a game store during Urza Block and watched as this one deck won week after week for two months straight. The acceleration back then was nuts, and jumping through Avalanche Riders, into Plow Under and going straight to Rain of Salt devastated deck after deck.

The crazy thing is: No one ever learned by being smashed by this deck. Every time they were Rain of Salted on turn four, they assumed the other guy was lucky/they were unlucky. They just kept bringing combo and control to the table because those decks were so powerful back then. Meanwhile, this one guy just kept playing Rain of Salt, and walking home with his winnings.
4359: Rain of Salt.text_posted:
I owned a game store during Urza Block and watched as this one deck won week after week for two months straight.  The acceleration back then was nuts, and jumping through Avalanche Riders, into Plow Under and going straight to Rain of Salt devastated deck after deck.  

The crazy thing is:  No one ever learned by being smashed by this deck.  Every time they were Rain of Salted on turn four, they assumed the other guy was lucky/they were unlucky.  They just kept bringing combo and control to the table because those decks were so powerful back then.  Meanwhile, this one guy just kept playing Rain of Salt, and walking home with his winnings.

4360: Scorching Spear.author: bfugitive
4360: Scorching Spear.text_parsed:
Listen up, kids. GengilOrbios has properly used 'strictly worse.' Follow along:

"strictly worse than gut shot"

Why? Because, Gut Shot provides the SAME EFFECT (1 damage to target creature or player) with MORE FLEXIBILITY (Instant vs. Sorcery, Phy mana vs Red only) at the SAME CMC and SAME COLOR.

It would be entirely wrong to call this strictly worse than Hornet Sting, however, this card is strictly worse than Shock, Lightning Bolt,Galvanic Blast, Burst Lightning, etc.


/soapbox

4361: Scorching Winds.author: tavaritz
4361: Scorching Winds.text_parsed:
After attackers are declared there is a window where fast effects can be played. This can be played then.

Rain of Blades and Sandstorm can also be played then, but they can be played after blockers have been declared and after damage assignments have been announced also and have effect. They can also be used on your own turn and outside an attack phase.

As there is almost no reason to play this on your own turn (eg. damage your own attackers) or outside attack phase, there is no lost functionality over Rain of Blades or Sandstorm. At least I cannot see why wait until blockers have been declared or after damage assignments have been announced to play those.
4361: Scorching Winds.text_posted:
After attackers are declared there is a window where fast effects can be played. This can be played then.

[autocard]Rain of Blades[/autocard] and [autocard]Sandstorm[/autocard] can also be played then, but they can be played after blockers have been declared and after damage assignments have been announced also and have effect. They can also be used on your own turn and outside an attack phase.

As there is almost no reason to play this on your own turn (eg. damage your own attackers) or outside attack phase, there is no lost functionality over Rain of Blades or Sandstorm. At least I cannot see why wait until blockers have been declared or after damage assignments have been announced to play those.

4373: Armageddon.author: blurrymadness
4373: Armageddon.text_parsed:
I don't always uprate darthparallax

but when I do, it's because he was actually funny.


That out of the way; cast this when you have 6 mana and you can Life from the Loam your way into lands with no trouble. Being Green/White means maybe you're running Garruk Wildspeaker making that a T4 play; giving you tremendous card advantage, board advantage, and probably the game. Best thing is that you don't *need* that play; it's just an awesome combo to have in the deck if you happen to get lucky.

Probably 3-4 of Garruk, 2-3 of Armageddon.
Harvest Wurms are great for this as well.

4375: Blessed Reversal.author: GainsBanding
4375: Blessed Reversal.text_parsed: This is an interesting case of a Portal card that's a reprint from Urza's Legacy.  Originally it was a regular instant in grown up Magic, so the oracle wording just disregards that "play only on your turn" line.  However, "instant" cards that were first printed in Portal always do get the Oracle line about playing on your turn.  It must be tough being in charge of errata.

4385: Gift of Estates.author: Stuflames
4385: Gift of Estates.text_parsed:
Land tax works on your upkeep, which means you may have to withhold laying lands (for longer) for its effect to work.

Tithe works for one land regardless of circumstance, but it can "only" get you a max of two lands instead of three.

They are all good cards, but one doesn't clearly outclass another.

4390: Regal Unicorn.author: DarthParallax
4390: Regal Unicorn.text_parsed:
http://wizards.com/Magic/Magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/ld/238

Regal Unicorn still is pretty good, actually! This article doesn't directly say it, but I grokked in the first two paragraphs looking at its examples that, basically, MAGIC Players for the most part from 1993 to 1998 (or, until about 6th Edition? Right before they made the first big Rules Book Update?), judging from the comments on Gatherer and the stories I see in online articles aboutthe game, seem to have for the majority been playing either what we would now call "Vintage" (All the broken Bad Designs of color-pie breaking and Bad Developments of mana-curve breaking or just plain Should Not Exist broken effects in one absurd combo deck) or "Limited" (Mostly Commons and Uncommons, with few people actually collecting the game enough to have Playsets of the Rares that were actually properly made. Most of the Rares being not-properly made added to how seriously uncommon a reasonable Constructed Deck was to find until at least post-Urza's Block, but the flavor of super-iconic just FUN to Look At cards like Shivan Dragon and Serra Angel and Lord of the Pit really carried the game and people didn't notice, didn't have enough meta-logic of the game to see it, or just didn't care that the commons and the rares were at horrendous disparity to each other compared to today.

OK, MYTHIC Rares have brought us a Return to STUPID disparity between cards....because people reported they liked Broken Power in their OWN decks, just not in OTHER people's decks. Of course they did. And MYTHIC Rare actually is fairly Fair in Comparison to Rare. It may be a huge leap from uncommon to Mythic, but it's less huge a leap from Rare to Mythic, and the Rares compared to the Uncommons really are Fair as well, and the Classic Rares from years goneby are still holding their own against weaker uncommons and most of the commons of today. That probably is as elegant an explanation as any for why Mythic Rares are simply not going anywhere. Hang on, I need to get back to talking about Pearled and Regal Unicorn.

Fistly, A3Kitsune, I think both Unicorns have great Flavor Text, and I wish I could steal the Lewis Carrol flavor text for a new common Unicorn today, but Regal Unicorn is apparently a good candidate for getting another Core Set reprint judging by the article I linked at the beginning's explanation of where WOTC Development likes to rate cards for Limited. "Bad" cards for Constructed are more than passable cards for Limited, and while specifically Dark Banishing itself is probably not quite strong enough to actually be offered to us in a Modern set, *some kind of a* 3-cost Common Black removal spell could be seen for Limited.

While it's true that Dark Banishing, Seraph of Dawn, Blind Phantasm, and even up to Mahamoti Djinn just don't make the cut for today's Standard standard, they ARE still perfectly valid cards to pick up in Limited as mid-pack picks. in fact, if they weren't at least good enough to see -some- Draft play, I'd say Limited was getting way overpowered.

We should rate Rares and especially Mythic Rares more on their useability for Constructed formats like Standard, Cube, and Commander. We should actually not expect too many cards per set to be "Clearly really good in Modern", in order to keep Standard and Limited fair; and for the Commons, it's just not right to compare them outside of the context of Limited, because Commons are Designed FOR Limited now, which is why we actually still see, in sets as recently as Avacyn Restored, cards that are functional reprints of Alpha Common Creatures.

The main difference between MAGIC today and MAGIC back then is not so much in the cards themselves, but in what percent of people's decks are Rare and Mythic nowadays as compared to before, because the Internet and Tournament Magic have exploded the card economy into a clear pecking order, and the Rares that aren't Spike enough for Pro Tour MAGIC are way way easier to acquire than the similar-ranked Rares were- the ones much much better than all the commons but not good enough for the Big League at all- back then.

4401: Temporary Truce.author: sarroth
4401: Temporary Truce.text_parsed: This card isn't terrible. Yes, you would be better off splashing blue or really any color if you wanted card draw in your white deck, but casual players don't always want to change the colors of their decks to open up their card options, a fact which is especially true in Commander as changing the colors would mean changing the commander chosen as well. This type of effect is exactly the type of card draw I would expect white to get. I just wish white got more of the Vision Skeins type effects than blue does, as blue has enough other card draw mechanics available that it doesn't need these too.
